glossdef.para: Desktop Grid : Loose opportunistic grid using idle computing resources (often desktop computers owned by volunteers).
No single desktop resource can guarantee any QoS, but a large desktop grid as a whole can provide a guaranteed QoS.
Trust is based on the certification of applications.
Most often, computing resources PULL jobs from desktop grid servers.
Service Grid : Federation of managed computing resources, offering a guaranteed Quality of Service according to a Service Level Agreement.
Trust is based on the Authentication of Users and Resources.
Often, grid Users PUSH jobs to Computing Resources, but pilot jobs PULL jobs from dedicated servers.
Bridge developed by the European EDGeS and EDGI projects to bridge Grid and Cloud DCIs which are intrinsically not interoperable
Prototype of grid middleware developed at INRIA
Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire : French research institute managed in collaboration between CNRS IN2P3 and Univ. Paris Sud.
XtremWeb for High Energy Physics : Robust grid middleware based on XtremWeb, and developed at LAL for usage on Desktop Grids and Service Grids.

refsection.title: Introduction on the Environment and Architecture
The 3G Bridge
refsection.para: The 3G Bridge is developed by the European EDGeS and EDGI projects in order to bridge various Grid and Cloud DCIs which are intrinsically not interoperable.

This 3G Bridge has a modular design, with :
A database and a queue manager at the core,
Job handlers to receive input jobs and work units from submitting DCIs,
Plugins to submit jobs and work units to target DCIs.

refsection.title: The XtremWeb-HEP grid middleware
refsection.para: XtremWeb-HEP is a grid middleware based on the XtremWeb prototype developed by INRIA.

XtremWeb-HEP is developed at LAL as a robust middleware for usage on Desktop Grids and Service Grids. In particular, it provides following features :
User management
In order to power Service Grids and to interoperate with other Service Grids, XtremWeb-HEP manages users, authenticates them, and authorizes actions on XtremWeb-HEP objects according to access rights. Besides the (user, password) pair, XtremWeb-HEP permits users to be authenticated by an X509 proxy, which facilitates interoperation with all grid middleware stacks authenticating users with X509 proxies.
Application management
DG (Desktop Grid) resources must receive only applications which are validated as secure and which comply to its architecture. Therefore, XtremWeb-HEP manages its own application repository.
Pull model
In order to be compatible with standard firewall settings of DG resources (authorize outbound, forbid inbound), the XtremWeb-HEP daemon running in the gathered computing resources pulls jobs from the XtremWeb-HEP server.
Easy gridification of applications
Contrary to the other DG middleware stacks which requires linking with specific middleware libraries, XtremWeb-HEP only requires that the submitted application is statically linked (or else that all necessary libraries are submitted inside the job alongside the application).
Agnosticism about data protocol
XtremWeb-HEP does not manage large data storage resources, but permits users and jobs to use any URI schema as data protocol, as long as the corresponding library is available to the job. In particular, the http: and xw: schemata are available natively, and the attic: schema is available as soon as the ATTIC library is submitted inside the job alongside the application.

In order to submit jobs to a given XtremWeb-HEP server, users must use the web site of this precise XtremWeb-HEP Server to download the corresponding XtremWeb-HEP client (available for Linux and Mac OS X). This XtremWeb-HEP client provides a CLI (Command Line Interface), but currently, its does not provide an API (Application Programming Interface).

refsection.title: Presentation of the XtremWeb-HEP plugin for the 3G Bridge
refsection.para: The XtremWeb-HEP plugin described in this document is the 3G Bridge plugin dedicated to submit jobs to DCIs powered by the XtremWeb-HEP middleware, and to retrieve job status and job results.
Therefore, usage of this XtremWeb-HEP plugin requires the connection to an XtremWeb-HEP server.

refsection.title: Architecture of the XtremWeb-HEP plugin for the 3G Bridge
refsection.para: The introduction inside the XtremWeb-HEP application repository of the applications submitted by users to the 3G Bridge is not performed online by the XtremWeb plugin, but is performed offline by the XtremWeb-HEP administrator.

The 3G Bridge itself is written in C++, and provides the abstract class GridHandler as template for plugins. Therefore, the XtremWeb plugin for the 3G Bridge is also written in C++, and implements the XWHandler class inheriting from the GridHandler class.
Since the XtremWeb-HEP client does not currently provide an API, the solution inside the XWHandler class is to use execv to call the CLI for each individual command.

refsection.title: File management inside the XtremWeb plugin for the 3G Bridge
refsection.para: Each time the XtremWeb plugin has to submit a job to XtremWeb-HEP, the 3G Bridge provides the list of input files and the list of awaited output files for this job.

listitem.para:
The XtremWeb plugin handles the job input files in the following manner :
For each input file given in parameter as URI, the XtremWeb-HEP plugin creates an XtremWeb-HEP data pointing to this URI (Here, the data agnosticism of XtremWeb-HEP is useful).
If the number of input files given in parameter as local files is exactly 1, the XtremWeb plugin simply gives it as environment parameter inside the submission command to XtremWeb-HEP.
If the number of input files given in parameter as local files is greater or equal to 2, the XtremWeb plugin packs all these input files into a single ZIP file, and gives this ZIP file as environment parameter inside the submission command to XtremWeb-HEP. On the computing resource, the XtremWeb-HEP daemon will automatically unpack this ZIP file.

As soon as the XtremWeb plugin sees that the XtremWeb-HEP Status of a submitted job is COMPLETED, the XtremWeb-HEP plugin retrieves the job results from XtremWeb-HEP, which packs these job results inside a ZIP file. The XtremWeb plugin then extracts from this ZIP file the files defined as job output files by the 3G Bridge.
